âœï¸ CRUD Operations

Learn how to create, read, update, and delete documents in BLite collections.

Insert

Add new documents to a collection:

Single Insert

var user = new User
{
    Name = "Alice",
    Age = 30,
    Email = "alice@example.com"
};

users.Insert(user);
// ID is automatically generated and assigned
Console.WriteLine(user.Id);

Bulk Insert

var batch = new List<User>
{
    new { Name = "Bob", Age = 25 },
    new { Name = "Charlie", Age = 35 },
    new { Name = "Diana", Age = 28 }
};

users.InsertMany(batch);

Async Insert

await users.InsertAsync(user);
await users.InsertManyAsync(batch);

Read

Find by ID

var user = users.FindById(userId);
if (user != null)
{
    Console.WriteLine(user.Name);
}

Find All

var allUsers = users.FindAll();

Query with Filter

var adults = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => u.Age >= 18)
    .AsEnumerable();

Update

Update Single Document

var user = users.FindById(userId);
user.Age = 31;
user.Email = "newemail@example.com";

users.Update(user);

Upsert (Insert or Update)

// Insert if not exists, update if exists
users.Upsert(user);

Partial Update

var user = users.FindById(userId);
if (user != null)
{
    user.Age += 1; // Increment age
    users.Update(user);
}

Async Update

await users.UpdateAsync(user);
await users.UpsertAsync(user);

Delete

Delete by ID

var success = users.Delete(userId);
Console.WriteLine(success); // true if deleted

Delete by Document

var user = users.FindById(userId);
users.Delete(user.Id);

Delete Many

var toDelete = users.AsQueryable()
    .Where(u => u.Age < 18)
    .Select(u => u.Id)
    .AsEnumerable();

foreach (var id in toDelete)
{
    users.Delete(id);
}

Async Delete

await users.DeleteAsync(userId);

Validation

BLite respects DataAnnotations attributes automatically:

public class User
{
    [Required]
    [StringLength(100, MinimumLength = 2)]
    public string Name { get; set; }
    
    [Range(0, 150)]
    public int Age { get; set; }
    
    [EmailAddress]
    public string Email { get; set; }
}

try
{
    users.Insert(new User { Name = "", Age = 200 });
}
catch (ValidationException ex)
{
    Console.WriteLine(ex.Message);
}

Best Practices

  • âœ… Use async methods for better scalability
  • âœ… Wrap writes in transactions for consistency
  • âœ… Use bulk operations for large datasets
  • âœ… Leverage validation attributes for data integrity
  • âš ï¸ Avoid round-trips - batch related operations
